explanation:
The correct operation uses \( x^{\square} \) which allows entering any exponent. The student selected \( x^{-1} \), which computes reciprocals (equivalent to \( x^{-1} \)). 

The error stems from conflating the general exponentiation operator (variable exponent) with the fixed reciprocal operation. The student likely interpreted "raise to a power" as requiring a negative exponent button, mistaking the fixed \(-1\) power as the universal exponent entry. 

This aligns with misunderstanding "to the power of" as requiring a pre-set exponent value rather than recognizing the need for a button accepting arbitrary exponents. It specifically differs from fraction/decimal misconceptions, as \( x^{-1} \) isn't a conversion tool but a distinct inverse operation.
